source.67dc88ae:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

pd.plotting.register_matplotlib_converters()
%matplotlib inline
source.b901bb28:
# Path of the CSV file to read
hofstede_model_path = "../input/hofstedes-6d-model-of-national-culture/6-dimensions-for-website-2015-08-16.csv"

# Fill in the line below: Read the file into a variable my_data
hofstede_model = pd.read_csv(hofstede_model_path, sep=';', index_col="country")

# Replace '#NULL!' values with NaNs
hofstede_model = hofstede_model.replace('#NULL!', np.nan)

# Drop the rows where at least one element is NaN
hofstede_model= hofstede_model.dropna()

# Convert numerical values from String to Int
exclude = ['ctr']
for col in hofstede_model.columns:
    if col not in exclude:
        hofstede_model[col] = hofstede_model[col].astype('int')
source.50749a42:
# The first five rows of the data
hofstede_model.head()
source.73d989ef:
# Bar plot illustrating the power distance index for each nation

hofstede_model_sorted_pdi = hofstede_model.sort_values(['pdi'], ascending=False)


# Create a plot
# Set the width and height of the figure
plt.figure(figsize=(10,30))


# The model was devised in the 1970s on the basis of questionnaires given to IBM’s employees in various nations.
# The six dimensions are measured on the scale from 0-100. 
# Some countries may have scored below 0 and others above 100 because they were measured after the original scale was made.

# Hofstede’s Power distance index measures the extent to which the less powerful members of organizations
# and institutions (like the family) accept and expect that power is distributed unequally. 
# This represents inequality (more versus less), but defined from below, not from above. 
# It suggests that a society’s level of inequality is endorsed by the followers as much as by the leaders.

plt.title("Hofstede’s Power distance index (PDI)")

# Add label for vertical axis
plt.ylabel("Nations")
plt.ylabel("Power distance index")

# Bar chart
sns.barplot(x=hofstede_model_sorted_pdi['pdi'], y=hofstede_model_sorted_pdi.index)

# Bar plot illustrating the individualism <-> collectivism index for each nation

hofstede_model_sorted_idv = hofstede_model.sort_values(['idv'], ascending=False)
plt.figure(figsize=(10,30))
plt.title("Hofstede’s individualism<->collectivism index (IDV)")

# Add label for vertical axis
plt.ylabel("Nations")
plt.ylabel("Individualism-collectivism index")

# Bar chart
sns.barplot(x=hofstede_model_sorted_idv['idv'], y=hofstede_model_sorted_idv.index)

source.25352c0a:
# **Importing dataset**
The dataset was taken from [this](https://geerthofstede.com/research-and-vsm/dimension-data-matrix/) website. Some processing is needed in order to make data usable. As said above, we replace '#NULL!' strings with NaNs. Then, we will drop all rows containing missing values.
